text.text: Lonely in London: 20 Ideas

We put on a brave (and very attractive) face, but we too have known what it is to be lonely in London, what feels like the default urban condition. Saying ‘wagwan?’ to a stranger can feel like the hardest thing in the world. 

One solution is to do something you like doing in the hope that the other people who like doing the thing that you like doing are people you might get along with. This is a varied selection of events, groups and places that we’ve found to be arms-open affairs, ripe for making pals.
1. Grow your friends organically

tip.text:
We know, we know, the name is misleading, but you could probably grow an elephant here if you really wanted to - though you'd need to have very little respect for nature, animals, the environment, the world, and we know you're not that kind of person. Instead, the people of Elephant and Castle have come together to grow fresh veg and summery flowers in movable raised beds, so those green fingers can run wild when you're not busy enjoying a warm cuppa from the on-site caff.

They also host regular events throughout summer - like workshops, live gigs, outdoor film screenings, yoga classes and poetry nights - and keep a small part of the garden sectioned off for volunteers to grow their own veg and relax. Just don't forget to bring some tweezers, pallet seating can get annoying.

There's at least one volunteering session per week, just email Paul to find out when.

text.text: A gardening and communal space, Grow Elephant are always looking for new volunteers to join the gardening gang, with one public access volunteering session every week alongside gardening workshops, film screenings, talks and live music. Quite simply, only good sorts make it down here - you'll fit right in.
More community gardens this way
2. Find your intellectual equal

tip.text:
You know that feeling when you're reading something truly thought provoking and you want to share in the joy but nobody cares? Well a book club is the answer. But shift your thinking from cardigans and cords and 'My First Erotic Novel', because this isn't any old fuddy duddy, this is the Rebel Book Club (don't worry, it's our first time too).

RBC covers a different non-fiction read each month, covering a wide range of topical social issues. Past reads include Blockchain Revolution; Why I'm no Longer Talking to White People About Race; How Not to Be a Boy; and Sleep Smarter. Do your homework, head along to the latest meeting and get stuck in to discussions on gender, race, happiness, utopias, veganism and more.

£15 a month gets you a monthly book voucher and a book-inspired cocktail at the meet up.

text.text: A book club might have you thinking of cardigans, cords and 'My First Erotic Novel', but Rebel do it slightly different. They cover a different non-fiction read each month, touching on all types of topical social issues with recent reads including Blockchain Revolution; Why I'm No Longer Talking to White People About Race; and How Not to Be a Boy. Sharing values on gender, race, happiness, utopia and veganism? The bedrock of any new friendship.
3. Running with friends

tip.text:
Tired of hearing the plod plod plod of little old me along the tarmac? Tribe running club are bringing together runners for regular runs all over London.

Set up by a team of passionate runners, Tribe keep things interesting by taking their troupe on lesser-known routes round London whilst they've also done collaborations with Frame, Stretch and Lomax to create active days out. Their snack boxes are expertly put together and full of plenty of goodness so subscribe to that to get the full Tribe package.

See their website page for details of their next run.

text.text: The clue is in the name - you could be part of a tribe (not to be confused with a cult). Making conversation during the run is not advised, especially when you inevitably get out of breath after the first 30 meters, but the runs typically precede some food or drink. Tribe are Dojo favourites but there are plenty around town which cater to almost all speeds.
Check our Mind & Body category for more running groups
4. Think of the karma

tip.text:
Arts charity Magic Me supports elderly communities in all sorts of lovely ways. Aiming to bridge the gap between generations, it gets young people involved in a number of projects with the elderly. These range from theatre productions to, our personal favourite, cocktails in care homes. These events give residents something to look forward to, plenty to gossip about for weeks afterwards and a chance to chat to some young'uns like yourself - especially important for those that don't have any visitors.

Once signed up you can pop along to one party a month (these happen all over London), serve drinks and have a proper natter with the residents. You'll likely meet some fine, friendly folk like yourself too.

text.text: Arts charity Magic Me supports elderly communities in all sorts of lovely ways doing things like theatre productions and, our favourite, cocktails in care homes. They have monthly meet ups where you'll be able to do some real good whilst also meeting some friendly folk just like yourself.
More volunteering projects

action.name: Give Back: Volunteer Projects in Your Community

text.text: 5. Go back to school

tip.text:
Did you know that it's possible to carry on learning after the age of 21? You did? Why didn't you tell us? Skills that we had accepted we'd never be able to master such as woodworking, sewing and pottery will still be skills we'll never be able to master but at least we can tell our friends how wholesome and meaningful our life is by taking part in some workshops.

The Adult Learning Centre in Peckham is just the place to embark on a voyage of self-betterment. They do courses in all sorts of tactile, hands-on subjects and the prices are pretty reasonable too; it's around £100 for 10 two hour lessons. Take a look at the list of courses they have and choose one. Commit. And then proceed to tell everyone you can find all about it.

text.text: It was easy to make friends at school (or at least that's how we're choosing to remember it), so let's go back. Southwark Adult Learning Centre have reasonably priced and extensive evening courses in all kinds of crafts: from woodwork to creative writing to oil painting. Sat next to someone who is similarly struggling to thread a needle is a shortcut to friendship if ever we saw it.
6. Organised Fun!

tip.text:
Last time we played tag, we had an overactive bladder filled with juiceboxes and gangly appendages that made us look like a wacky inflatable tube man. But now that we've grown into our limbs and tightened our pelvic floors, we reckon we'd smash it - luckily, Rabble brings together grown-ups to play traditional playground games, incorporating some HIIT into the session for a sneaky workout.

The idea is to have fun whilst getting fit, playing games and meeting people in a sociable environment. There are games across London on weeknights and weekends, and the sessions always end at the pub for a well-deserved adult bevvy. You can sign up for a single game and then buy a membership package if you get hooked.

text.text: Who the heck doesn't like organised fun? Rabble bring together grown-ups to play traditional playground games - the kind of good, clean fun you had resigned to the past. The idea is simple: have some fun, do something healthy, meet some nice peeps. There are games across LDN on weeknights and weekends, and the sessions always end at the pub.
7. Dinner for schmucks

tip.text:
Like all good house parties, The Little Yellow Door dragged on and on and on. Starting off as a three-month pop up bar with a homely atmosphere, a mish-mash interior of kitsch trinkets, and a menu of decadent bar snacks, it grew into something more with their rowdy weekend supper clubs. Three years later, and this bustling haunt is still kickin' it, having now re-opened in a permanent fixture in Fulham with a fresh lick of blue paint and all the same bits 'n' bobs that made it so loved.

Come down for one of their weekly supper clubs on Fridays and Saturdays which are filled with naughtiness, games and banging food, or pop by for a cracking roast on Sunday. If you're a weekday partier, then they've got some tasty bar grub to keep you going - think along the lines of crispy panko fried chicken or lobster and shrimp rolls teeming with flavour.

text.text: This one will take a little bit of courage, we admit, but Little Blue Door (formerly yellow) offers a communal dinner party leading into drinks and then games: the poster-boy formula for forming friendships/conducting swinging parties. The organisers are very welcoming and everyone there is there to mingle; be brave and you may well be rewarded.
8. A little live music

tip.text: Daylight Music at Union Chapel has become something of an institution with its mixture of a beautiful setting, diverse music, homemade cakes and general warming vibes. It isn't strictly classical music; all kinds of genres find their way onto the stage but we've caught plenty of piano soloists and string quartets in the past, including the likes of Nils Frahm, The London Bulgarian Choir and The Guildhall Saxophone Ensemble. They take short breaks during the year so check the website before making the trip.

text.text: An event to warm the cockles, Daylight Music is something of an institution: a free, weekly Saturday afternoon event in Islington's Union Chapel that combines a beautiful setting with diverse music, homemade cakes and tea out of a mug. You'll find a friendly, diverse crowd who are very easy to chat to, provided you're not talking over the music.
9. Cruise in a convoy

tip.text: Before you begin envisioning lycra clad macho men screaming through the London streets tanked up on beer, fear not: this cycling community group is a lot more laid back and relaxed than all that. In short, it's a group of friendly people who love cycling and want people to do that with. They set up plenty of quick and social rides with the basic aim of encouraging people to get on their bikes.

text.text: Before you begin envisioning lycra-clad macho men screaming through the London streets tanked up on pints, fear not: this cycling community group is a lot more laid back and relaxed than all that. In short, it's a group of friendly people who love cycling and want people to do that with.
10. Let your hands do the talking

listing.name: Pottery Class at Hackney City Farms
listing.subtitle: BYOB Pottery

tip.text: This pottery class is the most fun we've ever had with our fingers. This drop-in mid-week class (on Wednesday and Thursday evenings, though Wednesday tends to be less busy) will have you sculpting like Michelangelo, or maybe Demi Moore. It's BYOB, and the instructor frequently smokes the devil's lettuce in full view of the class. The style is more self-directed, but the instructor will guide you if you've never used a pottery wheel before. Your beautiful creation is fired after the class, and you have to arrange a time to come back to pick it up. We recommend ordering Franco Manca and picking it up halfway through the class. Pizza and pottery - ain't nothing better.

text.text: These drop-in classes (on Wednesdays and Thursdays) are BYOB affairs and pretty darn social - the instructor has even been known to smoke the devil's lettuce. Despite how people might appear, none of them are on course to be the next [insert famous potter's name]; everyone is in the same, slightly wonky clay boat. Although that sounds like it's going to sink.
11. Join the do-gooders

tip.text:
Spread those good workout feels with Good Gym. This not-for-profit running and fitness group is all about merging fitness and philanthropy - they organise groups that go on runs to community projects, and, once there, help vulnerable old people or community organisations with physical tasks. It's a great way to reconnect with the place you live and meet some fellow do gooders, and it's guaranteed to kick those endorphins into high gear.

With groups in several boroughs of London, go to their website to join and start doing a little good.

text.text: Another running group, but this one is slightly different. Good Gym stop off on their runs to do physical tasks for community organisations and to support older people with visits and tasks. For those out there with that level of virtue (yes, you!), this fits the bill.
12. Shake a leg

tip.text:
If you're partial to a retro, fast-paced boogie then Swing Patrol could be the one for you. A vague knowledge of your rights and lefts; and counting one to eight is advised, but not entirely required as there's plenty of people willing to help you out including teachers and friendly faced regulars. Classes come in all levels - from absolute beginner to intermediate - and attract a wide range of ages. Extra points for using gender neutral language, so anyone can 'lead' or 'follow' at their leisure. If you can work your way through the initial cringe, you'll be in for some real fun. We soon got caught up in the hop, jump, kick and - our personal favourite - the slide.

They have classes at various locations across London. Check online to find your closest lessons or skip along to one of the big evening events with a live band.

text.text: Stood mere millimetres away from a stranger whilst you stand clumsily on their toes is a fast-track past formalities. Swing Patrol put on their swing dance classes all over town and cover all levels. It takes a little work to get past the initial cringe, but once there you'll release all inhibitions. Nobody really looks cool swing dancing and that's the perfect leveller.
13. Feisty Feast

tip.text:
Julia was big into cooking, meeting people and just generally being an ace host. So she set up Feisty Feast with the aim of building communities of women who could learn from each other and have a little fun along the way. How, you ask? With an evening of talks from badass female speakers and a big ol' veggie sharing feast. Hear from Stine Dulong (of Skandihus ceramics); Muji Othol (Taia Botanics); Isa-Welly (Locoh-Donu pilates) and Beth Fuller (founder of Noa-Vee a beauty-standards-free online platform).

This time around the focus is self love... which means all sorts, from poetry on the topic to a mini-dance workshop promising to help you embrace your sensual side. And to finish off in style, a live music performance from sister act We Are Aya. If all that for £49 doesn't sound like a banging deal, then we don't know what does.

text.text: One for the ladies, as Feisty Feast aim to build female communities via an evening of talks from badass female speakers and the sharing of a big ol' veggie feast. Events take place every month or so and tickets are £49 which, when you consider the talks, food and potential of finding life-long friendship, seems okay.
14. Adult swim

tip.text:
Starting out in 2013, Swim Dem Crew is a rapidly growing inner city swimming club with those much sought after family vibes coursing through its veins. It fulfils several very noble functions, helping people lose their fear of the water, battle loneliness and improve mental health all whilst being part of something communal. A family looking to use their energy in a positive way.

The swims typically take place on Monday and Saturday. Monday is on that training flex, honing techniques and pushing bodies to their limits. Saturday is kind of a travelling swimshow, trying out a different pool around town before having breakfast and the like afterwards. To get involved, drop them a message on FB.

text.text: Swim Dem Crew is a rapidly growing inner city swimming club with those much sought after family vibes coursing through its veins. It fulfils several very noble functions, helping people lose their fear of the water, battle loneliness and improve mental health. Swims take place on Monday and Saturday.
15. A shared journey

tip.text: Pitchback Playback is, in short, listening to an album in its entirety on a crystal clear sound system in the dark. They've been doing it for a while now and people are really starting to like the whole process: sitting somewhere comfy, laying back and letting a classic joint course through your veins, transporting you to a place you've never been before as a much-loved album is elevated to a whole new dimension. Past editions have seen albums from Beyonce, Tame Impala, Frank Ocean, Pink Floyd, Radiohead and Childish Gambino. A spiritual, musical experience.

text.text: There's something about sitting in a pitch black room with a load of strangers that somehow bonds, much like a shared acid trip. Pitchback Playback put on listening sessions in the dark, playing a classic record (past editions have included Tame Impala, Beyoncé and Frank Ocean) on high quality speakers. This is a pleasant thing to rock to on your own, and reflect upon with someone else afterwards - provided they don't run off.
16. Stare at a stranger naked

tip.text: Sure, life drawing classes can be a little intimidating when everyone seems so goddamn good that it feels like they're all undiscovered artists on the verge of breaking into the mainstream. But put those insecurities in a sack because Soho Life Drawing is a supportive place suitable for experienced drawers and novices alike - beginners are actively encouraged. Their drop-in class run by the hour every Monday between 6.15pm to 9.30pm and cost from £8 for members to £12.

text.text: Some life drawers are a little stand-offish and elusive, doing their finest silent-genius routine. Plenty of others are not, though, and Soho Life Drawing is a supportive place suitable for experienced drawers and novices alike. Their drop-in class run by the hour every Monday between 6.15pm to 9.30pm and cost from £8 for members to £12 for new comers. To get past small talk, simply laugh at your prospective friend's drawing.
17. Climb a wall

tip.text:
We've all got that friend who's into bouldering and relentlessly bangs on about how great it is - The Arch in Bermondsey is a great spot to try it. Here there's 15,000 square feet of modern bouldering and training areas, all set inside a former Damien Hirst gallery. There are routes suitable for the most expert boulderer and routes so straight forward that even a drunk novice could do them. Although don't come here drunk.

An introductory class is £20 and is a very helpful way of learning the ropes. Although there won't be any ropes, for this is bouldering.

text.text: Despite being a solitary quest, bouldering is a super social sport and boulderers are famously friendly types. Roll down to a place like Bermondsey's Arch on a Saturday, take an introductory course and then go about it, chatting to people on the mats in-between climbs. Before you know it, you'll be sinking post-bouldering lattes in the cafe every week.
18. Bond over music

tip.text: Love Vinyl is potentially our favourite record shop in East. Opened by a crew of ex-ravers, DJs, journalists and music enthusiasts, their selection of funk, disco, jazz, house and everything in between is pretty much unrivalled. With numerous turntables this is a great place to stop by, try a few cuts out and see if they hit the spot. Their instore events are also great and worth keeping an eye out for.

text.text: Instores at record shops are, in our experience, good places to find like-minded pals - someone into the same music as you should be on the level. Love Vinyl in Haggerston put on regular instores within the realms of funk, disco and soul. Bop down here and flick through their excellent vinyl collection; start a conversation with a stranger about music. Before you know it, you'll be stumbing out the club together at 3am.
19. Take it to the beach

tip.text:
Roll on down to the Costa del Leyton where you'll find an unexpected beach volleyball club in the middle of an otherwise concrete, fairly desolate part of east London. It comes kitted out with five sand courts and a pretty ramshackle clubhouse with a cafe and bar that tricks you into thinking you're on a beach somewhere exotic, about to sink 5 piña coladas and get back out onto the sand.

The cost to book a court is about £20 p/h, whilst membership is £25 and comes with cheaper fees. They also do all you can play Saturdays and Sundays where you pay just £10 for all you can handle. Those wrists may well be red and sore by the end, but we rate this as a very fun bit of sport-fuelled escapism. Look out for numerous hunks and babes too.

text.text: As anyone who's been on a beach knows, a game of volleyball is a verified unifier. A trip to the Costa Del Leyton gets you to Sideout Volleyball: a social place with a range of sessions which are ideal for meeting people, playing a bit of vollers and then bonding in the clubhouse afterwards over a piña colada.
20. Join the eco-warriors

tip.text:
According to FoodCycle, UK supermarkets throw away 400,000 tonnes of food every year - which plain sucks, especially when so many Londoners are hungry. Join the good fight by volunteering with this charity, which takes surplus food from supermarkets, sets up in spare kitchen spaces across London and makes tasty, nutritious meals. This grub then get served up to the people most at risk of food poverty and social isolation - pretty neat right?

Check their website to find the FoodCycle hub closest to you and join a team of like-minded food waste warriors.

text.text: Join those fighting the good fight by volunteering with FoodCycle, which takes surplus food from supermarkets, sets up in spare kitchen spaces across London and makes tasty, nutritious meals to serve to those in need. At the time of writing there are 11 hubs in London - check their website to find your closest.
Shout out to Meet Up
